results.title: Why drown?
results.brief_description: Demonstrates “drown-proofing” developed by Fred Lanoue by showing how to survive for long periods in water in an emergency. Shows how to discard and use clothing, time breathing and reduce fatigue in detail. Features Lloyd Bridges and Murray Rose.

results.title: Why'd the beetle cross the road?
results.brief_description: In answer to the question which has puzzled sages throughout the centuries, this short whimsical film gives us a bug’s eye view of the meaning of life. It stars a determined beetle who slowly makes his way across an ocean-side bikepath, humming a medley of familiar tunes while he evades or surmounts a series of obstacles.

results.title: Whose neighbourhood is this?
results.creator_credit: Richard Gebhardt and Mitchell Gebhardt Film Co
results.brief_description: Deals with the problem of serious crime, including interviews with victims of robbery and assault, police, and criminals. Gives advice on locks and security. The film is aimed at a general audience, and takes a “common man” approach.

results.title: Who wrote that
results.creator_credit: Connecticut Mutual Life Assurance and Pelican Motion Pictures
results.brief_description: Illustrates common faults in business correspondence, suggesting how they can give unfavourable impressions. Discusses the principles of good letter writing.

results.title: Who cares about Jamie?
results.brief_description: Discusses the problem of metal health and suggests prevention as a solution. Follows James through a few hours of his young life and then analyses the reaction of adults involved. Stresses the role adults, particularly partner and teachers play: a child needs understanding at every stage of development if he is to acquire the capacity to face life.

results.title: White flood
results.brief_description: The film opens with a review of the forces that affect the surface of the earth - volcanic action, earthquakes, atmospheric conditions. A study of glaciers follows in which the life history of a glacier is examined from its birthplace in the mountains to the day when it floats into the sea.

results.title: White blood cells: defense against disease
results.brief_description: Shows how the white blood cells capture the diseased organisms and destroy them. Special cells not only destroy bacteria, but are also capable of removing white blood cells that have been overcome in their battle with the invading organisms. Removal of invading organisms prevents them from multiplying and overwhelming the body defences. Shows the white blood cells in all the various work they do.

results.title: White Australia Policy
results.creator_credit: Student Action of Melbourne University and Unifed Productions
results.brief_description: A documentary record culled from television and other news reports on the White Australia Policy as it found expression in topical incidents in 1961, 1962 and 1963. It is a protest against the White Australia Policy and a record of the events in the history of Student Action. Compiled and edited by Peter Tammer. Dedicated to the memory of Bill Thomas, student leader.

results.title: White-throat
results.brief_description: A nature film without commentary photographed in Canada’s Algonquin Park. A white-throated sparrow is the central character, but other inhabitants are included: young wolves at play, other birds, shoals of fish in a lake, and a beaver at work.

results.title: Which is my world?
results.brief_description: Shows how our demand for new things leads us to discard still usable items, how materials are consumed or permanently altered, and how the altered materials lie in mounds that scar our environment.
